meta-description.value: The landing page for DDB Group Australia.
About our principles at DDB Sydney.

headline.value:
How do brands and businesses actually grow?

The most urgent conversation in business today is growth. Yet we are living in a low to no growth world.

The problem for business today is that we are clinging to old theories. We believe we know how companies and brands grow. Scrape away the layers, and it focuses on a misplaced belief in reason.

The old theory that marketing and advertising succeeds because people are reasonable is just not true. In fact, we now know that people are highly unreasonable.

New evidence from the behavioral sciences shows that humans are emotional and often behave in a fashion that defies logic. Leading the debate is Nobel Prize winning Psychologist Daniel Kahneman who writes:

“We are feeling beings who can think, not thinking beings who can feel.”

Our research suggests that behaving in a reasonable, rational fashion is possible the most dangerous thing a business can do.

text.value:
Thinking Fast, and Slow.
<br class="all">- Daniel Kahneman

headline.value:
A Challenge to Conventional Business Thinking

There used to be three golden rules to grow your business:

1. Win Your Category
2. Win The Mind of Your Consumer, and
3. Win Today.


Instead, we propose three new rules:

1. Culture Dwarfs Category,
2. Feelings Conquer Thinking, and
3. Long Term Beats Short Term.

We propose new rules of growth that are sympathetic to the latest evidence of the primacy of the emotional mind:

Fame dwarfs category.
Feeling conquers thinking.
Long term Fluency beats short term wins.

Unreasonable Growth in Practice

We are using a simple, measurable and actionable approach to create ‘unreasonable growth in an age of unreason’ – based on feeling not thinking; culture, not categories; and the long term, not the urgent.

Our approach is already delivering success for clients such as Volkswagen and Expedia. Our tools and workshops help clients optimise their growth and our partnership with the world’s leading System 1 research agency Brainjuicer means we can measure and benchmark a company’s performance against ‘unreasonable growth’.

copy.value: This is how we got car buyers to open their eyes to the ŠKODA Octavia.
As a relative newcomer to the Australian automotive landscape, the ŠKODA Octavia lacked awareness. It did, however, deliver on quality, design and engineering.

We set about calling out all the traditional car advertising clichés, challenging buyers to look behind the curtain.
What they discovered was a brand determined to sell them a quality car vs. a clichéd image.
Sales for the Octavia have continued to strengthen since the campaign launched but more importantly awareness and saliency of the brand has a had  noticeable uplift.

headline.value: DDB runner up network of the year at AWARD
New thinking from DDB Australia to create 'unreasonable growth'

meta-description.value: New thinking from DDB to create unreasonable growth

headline.value: New thinking from DDB Australia & New Zealand to create 'unreasonable growth'

copy.value:
DDB has today, for the first time, released details of its new thinking to create ‘unreasonable growth’ for brands and business. The thinking is significant because it challenges the long-standing business premise that growth is anchored to a consumer who makes reasonable and logical decisions to advance their lifestyle.

Pioneered by DDB Australia and New Zealand, the thinking is based on the power of unchanging human emotions in a rapidly changing modern world. The central thesis is that we are now, more than ever, living in an “age of unreason.”

“The most urgent conversation in business today is growth. Yet we are living in a low to no growth world,” said DDB Australia’s Managing Director of Strategy and Innovation, Leif Stromnes.

“The problem for business today is that we are clinging on to old theories. The old theory that marketing and advertising succeeds because people are reasonable is just not true. In fact, we now know that people are highly unreasonable,” he said.

Stromnes said the evidence of unreasonableness and its centrality to the human condition had been slowly growing prior to this century, however in the last few years the unreasonable snowball has begun to gather momentum.

There used to be three golden rules to grow your business – 1. Win Your Category, 2. Win The Mind of Your Consumer, and 3. Win Today.

Instead, DDB Australia proposes three new rules – 1. Culture Dwarfs Category, 2. Feelings Conquer Thinking, and 3. Long Term Beats Short Term.

DDB Australia CEO Andrew Little said this represents a paradigm shift in theories of business management.

“All the evidence suggests that behaving in a reasonable, rational fashion is possibly the most dangerous thing a business can do,” Little said.

“Unreasonable growth – real, tangible, exponential growth – rarely comes from acting reasonably.”

“We believe that breakthrough growth is possible using our simple, measurable and actionable approach. We’ve invested more than $1m into the thinking and tools,” he said.

DDB Sydney Managing Director Nicole Taylor said DDB has been rolling this thinking out with multiple clients, including Expedia, McDonald’s and Volkswagen, with huge success.

“DDB is at the forefront of creative that’s about feeling not thinking; culture, not categories; and the long term, not the urgent,” Taylor said.

“And we’re already having success – creating unreasonable growth in an age of unreason,” she said.
Here's a handful of DDBers working across IT, Engineering, Creative, Strategy, Production, and Business Management.

Celebrating our humanity in all its diversity lies at the heart of DDB's creative culture.

<br class="all">
<br class="all">

It goes back to Bill Bernbach’s policy of hiring ‘talented and nice’ people.

<br class="all">
<br class="all">

It defines the way we behave and the way we treat each other. And in a very old human tradition we have a list of 5 behaviours to remind us – after all, to err is human.

We care about each other as human beings, not just workers.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We support each other in life, not just at work.

We talk each other up, never down.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We don’t pretend to be perfect. 
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We don’t know it all, we strive to learn more.

We welcome differences.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We stand up against inequality, prejudice and unconscious bias.

We see each other’s strengths rather than pick at weaknesses.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We share responsibility for the highs and lows.

We try to be honest and authentic.
<br class="all">
<br class="all"> 
We speak as human beings - no jargon, no bullshit.

DDB Australia is at the forefront of creative that’s about feeling, not thinking; culture, not categories; and the long term, not just the short term.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
We have been voted Australia’s most creative agency twice and won runner up AWARD network of the year in 2017. In 2016, DDB Sydney was the most awarded Australian agency at Cannes and had clients including Westpac, McDonald’s, Volkswagen, Skoda, Telstra, Unilever, Expedia, Johnsons & Johnson, BT financial group, Electrolux, Henkel, Society One, Barilla, Gillette.
<br class="all">
<br class="all">
DDB is part of DDB Worldwide, an Omnicom company. We have offices in Sydney and Melbourne and are part of the DDB Group, which is also made up of TRACK, Tribal, DDB Remedy and Mango.

meta-title.value: McDonald’s Create Your Taste Father Daughter | DDB Sydney

copy.value: The family restaurant where parents feel like grown-ups
Parents are always putting their children first, which often means compromising on what satisfies their own tastes and comfort for the sake of being a good parent.

That’s why up until Create Your Taste gourmet burgers with grown-up ingredients like haloumi and brie came along, a trip to Macca’s was usually just for the kids. There wasn’t much in it for mum or dad.
But in this Create Your Taste campaign, we celebrated the fact that (just for a moment), parents can now enjoy a little grown-up pleasure when they take the family for a meal at Macca’s…
… by amplifing the notion that parents will do just about anything for love.

Gourmet Burgers have changed the way people think about Maccas. It's no longer a quick fix just for the kids, but an experience the whole family can appreciate. To find out more about how we're helping Maccas change what they mean to Australians, give us a call.

meta-description.value: DDB Sydney attracts best global talent

headline.value: DDB Sydney continues to attract the best global talent with new hires

copy.value:
DDB Sydney continues to attract the best talent from all over the globe, with recent hires adding even more weight to their impressive pool of creative talent.

Argentina is worldly known for its football, beef and the Tango, but you can also add talented creative minds to that list. Creative duo Nicolas Smith (Senior Art Director) and Damian Martinez (Senior Copywriter) are, as far as they know, the first Argentinian creatives to have crossed the Pacific to Australia.

Together, they've won awards at major creative festivals across the world, including Cannes Lions, D&AD, Clio, London International Awards (LIA) and Effie, most notably for "Life Signs". DDB Sydney is their fourth agency together and their biggest move yet.

"We're very excited to work alongside some of the best creatives in Australia and the world,” Nicolas said.

"I'm loving this place. I even enjoy eating Vegemite,” Damian said.

Canadian Art Director Alex Newman joins DDB with a swag of international awards under his belt, including Cannes Lions, The AToMiC Awards, The One Show, The New York Festival and London International Awards. In 2014 he was named ‘Top 30 Under 30’ by Marketing Magazine.

Alex said he was drawn to DDB’s drive for world class creative and is looking forward to building projects that stretch the boundaries of what is considered ‘advertising’.

“Ben (Welsh, CCO) has put together a powerful team, talent from all over the world, which has created this kind of hot bed of creativity. It’s an exciting time to be joining DDB,” Alex said.

Sian Binder and Dave Govier join DDB as Creative Partners on McDonald’s. They have won a bunch of awards between them, including Cannes Lions, One Show, Clios and D&AD.

Previously Head of Art at Ogilvy Sydney, Sian has worked on impressive award winning campaigns with talented creatives, while globe trotter Dave most recently freelanced at The Monkeys, Leo Burnett and Cummins & Partners after returning to Sydney from the legendary Saatchi’s London.

Sian said she’s always admired DDB’s work.

“I’m excited to join DDB on the Macca’s team. DDB and McDonald’s have a well-established partnership and I’m looking forward to working alongside such collaborative and passionate people. And the opportunity to work on one of Australia’s most loved brands made the decision to move to DDB an easy one,” Sian said.

Dave’s highlights as Copywriter and Creative Director so far include winning the prestigious Carlsberg European Cup TVC for a small independent agency, helping the people of Ireland have another reason to drink alcohol in moderation by creating the outrageously successful Arthur’s Day annual celebration, along with Guinness’ very first global TVC which picked up a Cannes Lion.

“Some things I look forward to doing more of include creating great film, digital, outdoor, print, events, promos, shelf-wobblers and any other ways we haven’t yet thought of to make famous work,” Dave said.

DDB Sydney CCO Ben Welsh said he was excited to welcome these outstanding creatives to his team.

“DDB Sydney is growing, in a very deliberate way,” Welsh said.

“Our focus on diversity across the board, including getting more women into creative and management roles, continues to attract top class international and home grown talent, and means we continue to deliver stand out work for our clients,” Welsh said.

Hiring the best talent is one of the most important things we do at DDB. If you're talented and nice then we'd like to hear from you.
<br class="all"><br class="all"> Please send your CV to Sarah Crabbe.

headline.value: DDB runner up network of the year at AWARD

copy.value:
DDB won runner up network of the year at the AWARD Awards on 26 May 2017, receiving a whopping 34 Gold, Silver and Bronze pencils.

Standout campaigns from DDB in Australia and New Zealand include Volkswagen The Naked Ute, #comeonin for Sydney Opera House, McDonald’s “Anything for Love”, The Unconventional Oven for Kidsafe, Mum’s Wish and the URXXL series for Sky NZ and Lion ‘Welcome to the Other Side’.

“Producing creative work that’s about feeling not thinking; culture, not categories; and the long term, not the urgent is the heart of what DDB does. We’re proud to be recognized for work that has delivered brilliant outcomes for our clients,” DDB Sydney CCO Ben Welsh said.

“Being the number one New Zealand agency and second overall at AWARD was really pleasing. What was even more pleasing was winning the 16 pencils across a wide range of clients and categories,” DDB New Zealand CCO Damon Stapleton said.

“We are extremely proud to pool our disciplines to create powerful campaigns that successfully deliver behaviour change for good,” DDB Managing Director Dion Appel said.

headline.value: New ŠKODA campaign via DDB Sydney challenges normal car ad conventions

copy.value:
Škoda today launched a new brand campaign, via DDB Sydney, that centres on the idea that you don’t have to be famous to be brilliant.

Featuring clever Australians doing amazing things, and doing them differently, the campaign challenges the normal car ad conventions.

Škoda Australia Director Michael Irmer said that this innovative brand awareness campaign is unique in that it challenges the buyer to disregard the more obvious choices and, instead, consider Skoda.

“Škoda’s tagline, ‘Simply Clever’, encapsulates both the accessibility and the innovation of our cars and SUVs,” Irmer said.

“The brand campaign paves the way for an entirely new direction for Škoda in the shape of the Kodiaq. As the first affordable seven-seat SUV from Europe, it is a game changer, one that challenges not only the traditional market leaders in this family vehicle segment, but also far more expensive prestige models,” he said.

DDB Sydney Managing Partner Amanda Wheeler said the campaign pushes against category conventions to stand out in a cluttered market.

“In an unexpected approach for a car company, this Škoda campaign celebrates people who are brilliant but not famous,” Wheeler said.

“The idea of the campaign is to align the brilliance and inventiveness of these people with the brilliance and inventiveness of Škoda, helping to create a greater appreciation of the Škoda brand in Australia,” she said.

DDB Chief Creative Officer Ben Welsh said the campaign is sophisticated, subtle and aspirational, and features two Aussies who certainly aren’t household names but are nonetheless exceptional.

“In the first spot we meet Dr John O’Sullivan, the leader of the team who invented Wi-Fi, and a second to be launched in July features Aelita Andre, a 10-year-old artist who had her first art exhibition in New York at the age of four,” Welsh said.

“Too many people in this world are famous for being famous, while those who really contribute to society are often overlooked; this campaign beautifully highlights the simple genius and different thinking that has gotten our talent where they are today,” he said.

This is the biggest campaign for the Škoda brand this year and will run over three months across TV, outdoor, social, digital and retail nationally.
How we got Australia talking about a mystery prototype that didn’t exist.
The Amarok V6 is the most powerful pick-up truck in its class. But Aussies blokes couldn’t look past its European styling and see it for the class-leading truck that it was.
If Aussie drivers were going to judge our truck by its cover we had to change the cover.

subline.value: We built a completely new shell for the Amarok V6 that made it look as mean as the V6 engine that powered it.

copy.value: Next, we leaked spy shots of the 'mystery prototype' to editorial media channels, igniting excitement and debate amongst performance enthusiasts.

subline.value: While the debate continued, we invited four unsuspecting performance enthusiasts to put the prototype to the test. With no preconceptions holding them back, the drivers were amazed by its raw power.
We then revealed the identity of the prototype by retargeting our audience online, changing the conversation from a powerful prototype to the powerful Amarok V6.

Not only did we announce the launch of the new Amarok V6, generating a significant amount of intrigue and excitement but we also sold some utes. The Amarok V6 model made up 38% of the Amarok sales in the first month and has broken Amarok sales records every month since launch.

copy.value:
When Bill Bernbach started this agency, he had in mind precisely the kind of people he wanted to work here. 
There were two requirements: You had to be talented and you had to be nice.
If you were nice but without talent, sorry but you just wouldn’t do. 
If you were a great talent but not a nice person, he had no hesitation in saying ‘No.’
This is still our philosopyhy. So if you’re both, get in touch.

DDB Sydney is looking for an Account Manager to join the team.  We are looking for someone who is passionate about getting the job done. You are, in fact, the ultimate project manager, firing on all cylinders all the time. You assist in the execution of all marketing activities and you are able to anticipate the entire process, from who is involved, to what needs to get done, and how it all fits together. 

As an Account Managers you contribute to your client’s business through your strong understanding of the creative product and your role in its creation. You have a thirst for learning and can quickly pick up an in-depth understanding of the client, the client’s business and their consumer. You act and think creatively and strategically, contributing to the team, but also owning your projects and integrating around ideas. 

If you are interested please send your CV to our Talent Director Sarah Crabbe sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com

DDB is looking for a Senior Account Manager to join the team working on a brilliant integrated account.

We are looking for a Senior Account Manager with strong integrated experience across everything from TV to Digital/Content and Print. If you are an organised and buttoned down suit with a knack for building exceptionally strong relationships - we would love to hear from you!

If you are interested please send your CV to our Talent Director Sarah Crabbe sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com

DDB is looking for an established Account Director to join the team working on an exciting and fast paced account. We are looking for an Account Director with exceptional client service experience across everything from TV to Digital/Content and Print. You are also a strong people manager able to coach and inspire your team.

Account Directors at DDB are solution-oriented, always thinking about their business, anticipating issues, and implementing their vision to produce superior results. They lead, facilitate and look for opportunities to expand into other disciplines. 

If you are interested please send your CV to our Talent Director Sarah Crabbe sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com

DDB is currently looking for a range of creatives to join DDB on the back of some significant and exciting business growth. We are looking for creatives who have a passion for breakthrough creative ideas, contemporary thinking and execution plus a desire to learn and grow.

If you are interested in exploring these opportunities please send your folio to our Talent Director Sarah Crabbe sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com
How we reignited grown-ups childhood love of ice cream.

subline.value: While ice cream has long been a welcome treat, it’s far too often forgotten amongst the serious business of adult life. Our challenge was to keep Streets top of mind during Summer.
We created a hyper-contextual campaign suite with a cheeky tone of voice, placing targeted outdoor and online messaging to lighten up moments of daily routine.

copy.value: This included a collaboration with Google and PHD to achieve a world first within YouTube’s targeting and creative automation technology – tailoring our pre-rolls via dynamic audio and visual assets to be hyper-relevant, topical and ultimately fun to watch.

subline.value:
The campaign has now been running for two seasons, generating sales uplift across the portfolio and crucially recruiting new buyers for Streets. Each year, the work has earned significant national and international PR coverage, as well as strong consumer support across social media.

The YouTube collaboration successfully boosted ad recall and beat video completion benchmarks, while also delivering cost efficiencies for both production and media investment.

copy.value: DDB is looking for an established Account Director to join the team working on an exciting and fast paced account.

This how we created Australia's most successful Facebook automotive campaign.

headline.value: So what was the brief then?

subline.value:
The job was to raise the consideration of the new model Golf,
boost understanding of its advanced tech features and deliver
more test-drives to Volkswagen dealers.

headline.value: An idea that was destined to fail…

subline.value:
We developed an online series about a Volkswagen dealer given an
impossible task. The premise was to sell the ultimate city car in
an outback town filled with folks with no want or need for it.
Our rep Tom made a grand total of zero sales in the town but on Facebook, where the series was shown, viewers loved every awkward minute.

We turned Facebook into our broadcast channel, so we could
directly target potential buyers with the 6-month series.
The most successful Australian Volkswagen campaign ever.

value.text: The most successful automotive Facebook campaign ever in Australia.
Consideration for the Golf hit an all-time high of 18.2% nationally.

copy.value: This is how we are helping next generation Australians' financial future with Bump.
For 200 years, Westpac has been supporting all Australians. To mark the anniversary, Westpac wanted to help Australian families secure their future.
For the first time we are looking at a situation where today’s children will grow up to have a lower quality of life than their parents.
We created the Westpac Bump account.  All babies born in 2017 will be eligible for the Bump account, which comes with an initial balance of $200 – a gift from Westpac.

subline.value: Savings cannot be accessed until the child turns 16, so with small weekly contributions and a modest interest rate, the Bump account could be well past $20,000 by the time it matures!

copy.value: Bump has generated phenomenal interest amongst families across Australia.
We needed to get more people inside the Sydney Opera House during summer

subline.value: 8.2 million people visit the Sydney Opera House every year. Most take a photo of the outside and move on, making it the most Instagrammed icon in Australia.
Turn photos of the Sydney Opera House on Instagram into incredible experiences inside by inviting users to #comeonin.
Invitees posted photos of their experience inside, changing perceptions of the House, one pic at a time.
126 unsuspecting instagrammers surprised with invites inside. Here are some of them.

Custom software uses computer vision to identify photos of the
famous sails along with geo-location to find ones posted in close proximity.
An on-site response team picks an Instagram user for an experience and quickly films and posts a video response inviting them inside.

In 4 weeks, over 5 million people saw a new side to the Sydney Opera House: 
the inside.

value.text: Social engagement up 30% from campaign launch.
5 million people got to see the magic that goes on inside the Sydney Opera House.

to solve big problems, with radical technology
solutions we have a place for you in POD.

Westpac wanted to show it supports all Australians.
<br class="all">See how we used a helicopter to do it.
Approaching its 200th anniversary, Westpac wanted to reaffirm its support for all Australians and launch its refreshed brand.
Everyone appreciates the work done by the Westpac Rescue Helicopters, which have been helping Australians out of adverse situations since 1975.
We used the Westpac Rescue Helicopters to demonstrate how Westpac really does support all Australians – even if they’re not Westpac customers.
The campaign resonated strongly with people across Australia (especially with our toughest audience, millennials) and had spontaneous brand attribution of 80% after just 2 weeks.

copy.value: Got the appetite?  Macca’s will bring the opportunity.
Working at McDonald’s is typecasted as a role for 15 year olds flipping burgers.
We needed to dispel the ‘McJob’ stereotype by evoking a sense of pride and admiration for the people who work at Macca’s.

At Macca’s, we believe the desire to work should never be wasted. That everyone has the potential to contribute something great. If you have the desire, passion, zest, appetite…
McDonald’s will bring the opportunity.
To bring this to life, we collected the stories of some of Maccas’ most remarkable crew members, shining a light on the way the business backs young Australians for a better future.
We then created a launch film, supported by 5 personal stories that build richer, emotive connections with our crew, inspiring future Macca’s employees to follow in their footsteps.
DDB is currently looking for a range of creatives to join DDB on the back of some significant and exciting business growth.

We are looking for creatives who have a passion for breakthrough creative ideas, contemporary thinking and execution plus a desire to learn and grow.<br class="all"><br class="all">

If you are interested in exploring these opportunities please send your folio to our Talent Directorb Sarah Crabbe  sarah.crabbe@syd.ddb.com<br class="all"><br class="all"><br class="all">
Aussie blokes were judging the Amarok by its cover, so we removed it.

The Amarok’s sleek European styling led people to believe
that it was too precious to handle tough Australian conditions

subline.value:
We stripped the Amarok of everything that identified it,
forcing critics to judge it on performance alone.

We asked some of the Amarok’s greatest sceptics to guess
what it was, while the public guessed along with them.
We then revealed that the tough Naked Ute was actually the Volkswagen Amarok, challenging their prejudices, perceptions and outdated opinions on how the Amarok really performs.
A total reach of 7.7 million with 125,000 unique visitors to our unbranded website, more than 24,000 guesses and an an immediate uplift in sales.
